metadata.case_name: Bar Council of Uttar Pradesh v. State of Uttar Pradesh

facts.text: The Advocates Act 1961 was enacted by Parliament and published on May 19, 1961.
Notification dated August 7, 1961 fixed August 16, 1961 as date for Chapters I, II and VII of Advocates Act to come into force; Bar Council of U.P. constituted thereafter.
Notification dated November 24, 1961 brought Chapter III of Advocates Act into force with immediate effect.
Under Chapter III of Advocates Act, State Bar Councils and Bar Council of India tasked with admission and enrolment of advocates; State Bar Council to prepare and maintain roll.
State Bar Council required to enter names of advocates from High Court rolls under Indian Bar Council Act 1926 before December 1, 1961, and new admits after.
Section 24(1)(f) of Advocates Act requires payment of Rs. 250/- enrolment fee to State Bar Council for admission as advocate.
U.P. Stamp Amendment Act 1962 amended Article 30 of Schedule 1-B of Indian Stamp Act, imposing additional Rs. 500/- stamp duty on entry as advocate on U.P. State roll.

Uttar Pradesh Taxation Laws Amendment Act 1969, effective October 1, 1969, amended Article 30 to impose Rs. 500/- stamp duty on certificate of enrolment under Section 22 of Advocates Act by State Bar Council U.P., retrospectively.

Indian Stamp (U.P. Amendment) Act 1970 substituted clause (c) in Section 11(1) and inserted Article 17A in Schedule 1-B, prescribing Rs. 250/- stamp duty on certificate of enrolment under Section 22 issued by State Bar Council U.P., omitting Article 30.
Bar Council of U.P. filed petition under Article 226 challenging U.P. Stamp Amendment Acts from 1962 onwards.
Single judge of Allahabad High Court allowed writ petition on November 12, 1963, holding amendments invalid.
Division Bench of Allahabad High Court allowed special appeal No. 143 of 1964 on July 9, 1970, setting aside single judge's judgment.
Under Indian Bar Council Act 1926, Section 8 required payment of stamp duty under Indian Stamp Act 1899 and fee of Rs. 10/- to Bar Council for enrolment.
Section 18 of Advocates Act allows transfer of name from one State Bar Council roll to another without additional fee.
Amendments received President's assent, complying with Article 254(2).

legal_issues.text: Whether provisions of U.P. Stamp Amendment Acts imposing stamp duty on certificate of enrolment issued by State Bar Council under Advocates Act 1961 are invalid and unconstitutional, given Section 24(1)(f) prescribing only Rs. 250/- fee.
Whether levy of stamp duty encroaches on Parliament's exclusive competence under Entries 77 and 78 List I regarding persons entitled to practise before Supreme Court and High Courts.
Whether there is repugnancy under Article 254 between Advocates Act and U.P. Stamp Amendments.
Whether levy is discriminatory under Article 14.

petitioner_arguments.text: Stamp duty is a condition precedent to enrolment and right to practise, within Parliament's exclusive field under Entries 77/78 List I; State encroaches by imposing additional duty.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Advocates Act 1961 s.24(1)(f); Constitution Entries 77,78 List I

petitioner_arguments.text: Parliament deliberately omitted stamp duty requirement from Advocates Act, repealing prior provisions; State levy repugnant.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Constitution Art.254; Advocates Act repeals s.8 Bar Council Act 1926

petitioner_arguments.text: Discrimination under Art.14: Advocates in other states pay only Rs.250/-; U.P. requires extra stamp duty; transfers to U.P. attract duty unlike other states.

respondent_arguments.text: Stamp duty is pure taxation under Entry 63 List II and Entry 44 List III; not a condition for enrolment under Entries 77/78 List I.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Constitution Entries 44 List III, 63 List II, 96 List I

respondent_arguments.text: No repugnancy as fields distinct; President's assent under Art.254(2) given.

court_reasoning.text: Advocates Act falls under Entries 77/78 List I; Rs.250/- fee under Entry 96 List I; but stamp duty is taxation under Entry 44 List III and rates under Entry 63 List II, not encroaching on List I.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Taxation distinct from main legislative subjects; pith and substance of stamp duty is tax.

court_reasoning.text: No repugnancy under Art.254 as State has competence in Concurrent List Entry 44; President's assent given.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Repugnancy only where both legislate in Concurrent List.

court_reasoning.text: Art.14 inapplicable where Parliamentary and State legislations from different sources.

holdings.text: State Legislature competent to levy stamp duty on enrolment certificates under Entry 44 List III and Entry 63 List II; no encroachment on Parliament's field.

precedents_cited.relevance: Stamp duty on document giving right to plead falls within State taxing power.

precedents_cited.case_name: Prem Nath Kaul v. State of Jammu & Kashmir
precedents_cited.relevance: Repugnancy arises only where both Parliament and State competent in Concurrent List.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of Jammu and Kashmir v. M. S. Farooqi
precedents_cited.relevance: Distinguished; Art.254 applied differently in J&K context.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of Madhya Pradesh v. G. C. Mandawar
precedents_cited.relevance: Art.14 inapplicable where sources of Parliamentary and State legislation differ.

precedents_cited.case_name: G. N. Mohindroo v. Bar Council of Delhi
precedents_cited.relevance: Advocates Act covered by Entries 77/78 List I; power over persons entitled to practise exclusive to Parliament.

precedents_cited.case_name: M. P. V. Sundaramier & Co. v. State of Andhra Pradesh
precedents_cited.relevance: Taxation treated as distinct matter for legislative competence.

statutes_cited.name: Advocates Act, 1961
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs admission, enrolment, rolls, certificates, qualifications, fee of Rs.250/-, right to practise; integration of Bar.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Stamp Act, 1899
statutes_cited.relevance: Amended by U.P. Acts to levy stamp duty on enrolment certificates.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Bar Councils Act, 1926
statutes_cited.relevance: Prior law on Bar Councils, admission, enrolment requiring stamp duty and fee.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
sections: Entries 77,78,91,96 List I; 63,66 List II; 26,44 List III
statutes_cited.relevance: Legislative competence, repugnancy, equality, judicial review; distribution of powers.

statutes_cited.name: U.P. Stamp Amendment Acts (1962, 1969, 1970); U.P. Taxation Laws Amendment Act 1969
statutes_cited.relevance: Imposed stamp duty on enrolment certificates.

statutes_cited.relevance: Prior power of High Courts to make rules for advocates.

outcome.summary: Appeal by special leave against Allahabad High Court Division Bench judgment upholding U.P. Stamp Amendments dismissed; State competent to levy stamp duty on enrolment certificates as taxation measure; no repugnancy or discrimination.

key_quotes.text: "It is well settled that the scheme of the Entries in the various Lists is that taxation is not intended to be comprised in the main subject... but is treated as a distinct matter for the purpose of legislative competence."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Distinguishes taxation from regulatory fields like enrolment conditions.

key_quotes.text: "A question of repugnancy can only arise in matters where both Parliament and State Legislature have legislative competence to pass laws, that is, when the legislative power is located in the Concurrent List."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "In order to achieve uniformity it is for the States to refrain from levying any stamp duty on the certificates of enrolment or for Parliament to enact proper legislation..."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Expresses dissatisfaction but upholds State power.
